Introduction

Leprosy (Hansen disease) is a chronic destructive infection of peripheral nerves caused by the Mycobacterium leprae complex.  Untreated, it causes neuropathic damage to the skin, upper respiratory tract, and eyes.  Although largely eradicated from most Western countries, it is considered a neglected tropical disease with a significant public health impact.

Pathogenesis

Microbiology



The M leprae complex includes 2 subspecies (M leprae and Mycobacterium lepromatosis) that produce clinically equivalent disease.  These pathogens are slow-growing, acid-fast bacilli (AFB) with cell walls rich in mycolic acids.  As obligate intracellular pathogens, they require living cells to survive and cannot be cultured with standard techniques.  Like other mycobacteria, the M leprae complex has virulence factors that resist phagolysosomal digestion (eg, cord factor, lipoarabinomannan) to enable intracellular survival.

Transmission



The major route of transmission is human to human via respiratory droplets, with minor spread through direct contact with skin lesions.  Most healthy individuals are at low risk for acquiring M leprae due to natural immunity (eg, 5% lifetime risk even if living with a person who is infected).  Risk factors include:



  • Poverty and overcrowding.
  • Endemic regions (over 90% of cases occur in India, Indonesia, or Brazil).
  • Poor innate immunity (eg, polymorphisms affecting macrophage function).
  • Close contact with armadillos (most common mechanism of transmission in the United States).

Immune response



The most common outcome after M leprae complex exposure is asymptomatic clearance by macrophages.  If the bacilli survive, they eventually invade the peripheral nerve sheaths (eg, entering through receptors on Schwann cells).  M leprae complex bacteria prefer cooler environments just below body temperature, so they mainly affect superficial cutaneous nerves.  Due to the very slow replication rate of these pathogens, skin lesions may not appear for 5-10 years.



The severity of infection is determined by the cell-mediated immune (CMI) response.  The required CMI response appears to be specific to M leprae (ie, leprosy is not associated with globally suppressed cellular immunity, such as HIV infection or reactivation tuberculosis).  The Th1 component of CMI, where CD4+ T cells produce IFN-γ to stimulate granuloma formation, is particularly critical.  For poorly understood reasons, some patients have an effective Th1 CMI response to M leprae, whereas others do not.  The effectiveness of the Th1 CMI determines whether patients develop limited lesions (tuberculoid leprosy) or extensive lesions (lepromatous leprosy).

Clinical presentation

Tuberculoid leprosy



Patients with an effective Th1 CMI response develop tuberculoid leprosy, a milder form of disease with:



  • Low bacterial burden (paucibacillary) due to successful immune control.
  • A small number of sharply demarcated skin lesions, reflecting a strong CMI response that limits infection to single or few superficial nerve branches.  The bacilli spread outward along the nerve territory but are confined by a strong granulomatous response.  This produces distinctive macules and plaques with a denervated anesthetic center surrounded by a well-defined inflammatory (sometimes painful) border at the leading edge of infection (
    image 1
    ).


Patients with tuberculoid leprosy may experience negative cosmetic effects from skin lesions but typically do not have significant peripheral nerve damage.

Lepromatous leprosy



Patients with an ineffective Th1 CMI response develop lepromatous leprosy, a more severe and diffuse form of disease with:



  • High bacterial burden (multibacillary) due to poor immune control.  Rather than a strong Th1 response, patients instead exhibit a humoral (Th2) response, producing antibodies that are ineffective against intracellular organisms such as M leprae.  Therefore, the bacilli continue to proliferate within lesions.
  • Numerous widespread skin lesions with ill-defined borders, reflecting free bacterial spread across adjacent peripheral nerve territories.


Extensive nerve destruction leads to polyneuropathy affecting multiple body regions (eg, extremities, trunk, face).  In late stages, sensory neuropathy produces anesthetic patches of skin.  With diminished pain and temperature sensation, relatively minor injuries can go unnoticed, leading to nonhealing ulcers and bacterial superinfection (necessitating amputation in severe cases).  Corneal anesthesia can eventually lead to undetected abrasions, scarring, and blindness.  Facial nerve involvement produces thickened, corrugated skin (eg, leonine facies (

image 2
)), frequently with destruction of the ears and nose.  Disfigurement contributes to social stigma and isolation (eg, leper colonies).



Less commonly, motor neuropathy can produce muscle atrophy and weakness (eg, foot drop) and autonomic neuropathy can produce alopecia and anhidrosis.

Borderline leprosy



Borderline leprosy represents an intermediate state between tuberculoid and lepromatous disease, with:



  • Moderate bacillary burden.
  • Mixed skin findings, such as few lesions (a tuberculoid feature) with ill-defined edges (a lepromatous feature) or numerous widespread lesions (a lepromatous feature) with sharply demarcated edges (a tuberculoid feature).


Borderline leprosy can shift between forms.  The lepromin skin test evaluates CMI and can help identify patients with borderline leprosy who are at risk for progression to lepromatous leprosy (

figure 1
).  The test involves subdermal injection of heat-killed M leprae extract followed by assessment for induration over 24-72 hours:



  • Positive:  Induration (≥5 mm) indicates robust CMI response (lower risk).
  • Negative:  Lack of induration indicates poor CMI with inability to form granulomas (higher risk).

Diagnosis



A presumptive diagnosis of leprosy can be made with any one of the following:



  • Characteristic skin lesions with focally reduced sensation.
  • Thickened peripheral nerve with a corresponding motor or sensory deficit.
  • Presence of AFB on full-thickness skin biopsy or smear.


Definitive diagnosis requires detection of M leprae on skin biopsy via PCR because the organism cannot be cultured.  Skin biopsy also assesses the bacillary load, enabling classification as tuberculoid or lepromatous leprosy.  Samples should be taken from the leading edge of the skin lesion, where bacilli are most abundant:



  • Tuberculoid lesions exhibit minimal AFB and tight granulomas, consistent with a good CMI response.
  • Lepromatous lesions exhibit copious AFB and loose macrophages (without granulomas), consistent with a poor CMI response.

Management

Multidrug treatment



First-line treatment of leprosy involves multidrug treatment (MDT):



  • Tuberculoid:  rifampicin + dapsone (± clofazimine) for 6 months.
  • Borderline or lepromatous:  rifampicin + dapsone + clofazimine for 12 months.


Rifampicin is an RNA polymerase inhibitor that is administered monthly, dapsone is a folate antimetabolite that is given daily, and clofazimine is a DNA intercalator also given daily.  The long duration of treatment is necessary due to the very slow replication rate of M leprae.  MDT clears roughly 90% of the total M leprae burden after a full treatment course, typically resulting in clinical cure (ie, complete resolution of skin lesions).  Early treatment is essential because neuropathy and tissue destruction are irreversible in later lepromatous stages.

Immunologic reactions



When MDT is initiated, 2 immunologic complications can occur as M leprae are lysed and release antigens into the extracellular space.  These reactions are mainly seen in patients with high preexisting antigen load (ie, multibacillary lepromatous leprosy):



  • Type 1 (reversal reaction):  Antigen exposure acutely reactivates CMI (reversing previous anergy), which can exacerbate neuropathy and existing skin lesions.  Management involves a brief course of systemic corticosteroids (eg, prednisone) to dampen the inflammation and supportive care with analgesics (eg, nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs).  (This process is roughly analogous to the transient worsening of CNS inflammation seen upon initiating treatment for tuberculous meningitis.)
  • Type 2 (erythema nodosum leprosum):  Circulating immune complexes (ie, type III hypersensitivity) deposit in tissues, causing multiorgan inflammation.  Patients can develop erythema nodosum, panniculitis, glomerulonephritis, ocular inflammation (eg, uveitis), and worsening neuropathy.  Treatment involves systemic corticosteroids and thalidomide (a cost-effective immune modulator readily accessible in resource-limited settings).


In addition, type 3 (Lucio phenomenon) is an immune complex–mediated systemic vasculitis that can occur in patients with untreated leprosy.  Its defining feature is severe skin and multiorgan damage.  Patients develop rapidly enlarging gangrenous skin ulcers.  Systemic involvement includes glomerulonephritis, acute liver injury, and optic neuritis.  The Lucio phenomenon is associated with high mortality due to sepsis from secondary bacterial infections.  Treatment includes urgent MDT to reduce M leprae antigen load and systemic corticosteroids to control inflammation.

Prevention



There is currently no vaccine for primary prevention, although the Bacillus Calmette-Guérin vaccine is sometimes used (due to its structural homology with Mycobacterium tuberculosis) in some areas with exceptionally high transmission.



Close contacts of patients with leprosy can receive postexposure prophylaxis with a single dose of rifampicin.



Individuals with leprosy often face ostracization from their communities.  Many choose to live in self-imposed exile.  However, isolation makes the disease more difficult to treat and eradicate.  Major efforts focus on public education (eg, leprosy is curable and not highly contagious) and supporting social reintegration at all stages of disease (eg, allowing patients to work and attend school).

Differential diagnosis



Skin lesions and sensory neuropathy are the defining characteristics of leprosy, but several other conditions are on the differential.

Other neglected tropical diseases



Several tropical infections can cause skin and mucosal destruction.  These conditions tend to cause open suppurative wounds that can mimic ulcerated lepromatous lesions:



  • Yaws is a chronic, typically painless, ulcerating skin and soft tissue infection caused by Treponema pallidum (subspecies pertenue), leading to bone and cartilage erosion.  It is treated with penicillin.
  • Tropical ulcer is a chronic, typically painful infection due to Mycobacterium ulcerans.  It affects the feet, ankles, and forelegs (eg, due to lack of protective footwear).  Polymicrobial superinfection (eg, with anaerobes) is common:  It leads to destruction of skin, underlying fascia, and bone and is treated with wound debridement and broad-spectrum antibiotics.
  • Cutaneous leishmaniasis is a protozoal infection transmitted through the bite of sandflies.  It presents with an enlarging painful ulcer with a necrotic base at the bite site.  It is treated with pentavalent antimonials (eg, meglumine antimoniate and sodium stibogluconate).

Infiltrative skin disease



Several infiltrative disorders can cause skin thickening (pachyderma) that resembles leonine facies of lepromatous leprosy.  However, unlike in leprosy, skin sensation is preserved:



  • Sarcoidosis can present with lupus pernio, which involves dermal infiltration by granulomas, causing induration, hardening, and deformity around the nose, cheeks, and lips.
  • Cutaneous T-cell lymphoma (mycosis fungoides) involves dermal infiltration by malignant T cells, causing diffuse induration, erythema, and exfoliation.  Systemic B symptoms (eg, fever, pruritus) are typically seen.
  • Acromegaly (eg, pituitary adenoma) involves dermal infiltration by collagen and mucopolysaccharides.  Coarse facies, macroglossia, jaw protrusion, and frontal bossing are typically seen.

Other chronic infections



Leprosy can be mistaken for other chronic infections affecting skin and soft tissue:



  • Tertiary syphilis can present with gummas, inflammatory masses that cause progressive tissue destruction and disfigurement.  It may also be associated with focal neurologic deficits (eg, tabes dorsalis) due to CNS involvement (unlike peripheral neuropathy in leprosy).
  • Dermatophytosis (eg, tinea corporis, pityriasis versicolor) are superficial fungal infections that present with annular scaling macules or patches, often with hypopigmented centers.  Unlike in leprosy, the lesions are typically pruritic rather than insensate.
  • Other mycobacteria that can affect the skin include cutaneous tuberculosis (verrucous lesions, usually with active pulmonary tuberculosis) and Mycobacterium marinum (pustules with ulceration, associated with aquarium or fish exposure).

Summary



Leprosy (Hansen disease) is a chronic infection caused by Mycobacterium leprae that primarily affects the peripheral nerves, skin, and upper respiratory tract, leading to tissue damage and disfiguration if left untreated.  Disease severity depends on the host cell-mediated immune (CMI) response.  Effective CMI is associated with tuberculoid leprosy, a clinically milder form with low bacterial burden and limited skin lesions.  Ineffective CMI is associated with lepromatous leprosy, a clinically severe form with high bacterial burden, widespread lesions, and neuropathic disfiguration (eg, of the face or eyes).  First-line treatment involves multidrug therapy with rifampicin, dapsone, and clofazimine taken for extended durations.  Combatting social stigmatization is an important part of helping patients engage with treatment and reintegrate into their community.
